Our wonderful
 world 
 
 Herminder Ohri
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time long ago, when there 
 were no people, God loked down at the 
 
 beautiful world he had made. 
 
 He thought I must have someone to lok 
 
 after my creation. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The lion roared, "I am the king of the
 jungle, I can lok after the world."
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The elephant trumpeted loudly, "My Lord, 
 you have made me so big and majestic. 
 
 Surely I am right for the job." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The whale loked up at the sky and spouted a fountain of
 water, "Do they know how to swim and lok after the fish, the
 
 refs, the coral and milions of tiny sea animals?"
 "I can lok after the oceans. I can also kep my head above
 water and se what is going on on the land. I am so LARGE,
 
 no one wil dare to do anything against your wil."
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The shark thought his sharp teth were 
 al that were neded to do the job. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The eagle laughed, "These animals can
 only lok after those on land, while the
 
 whale and the shark can only se the
 water animals. But I fly, I se the sky, land
 and water. I am the only one fit to be the
 
 keper of the world." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 God listened carefuly to the animals, to the fish and the
 birds. 
 
 
 "I wil create man," he said. The animals al wondered, what
 was this thing caled "man". 
 
 
 What colour, with feathers or fur, or scales? 
 
 Wil he run like the lion? Swim like a fish? 
 Fly high like the eagle? 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The sun had set and it was night. He wraped himself in the 
 
 night sky, put the twinkle of stars into the eyes and used the 
 black clouds for hair. He also put pieces of the mon in the 
 nails and the shine of far away stars in the teth. 
 
 
 So the first man and woman were created with shiny black 
 
 skins like the night. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Son the night faded and it was morning.
 
 God covered himself in the white
 
 morning light, tok the blue sky for the
 eyes, the gold of the sun he spun into
 hair, and before him stod a man and
 
 woman with white skins, blue eyes and
 golden hair. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Now the morning had turned into 
 
 afternon. The sun was very bright, so he 
 puled the yelow light, and the dep 
 black shadow of the afternon and made 
 
 a man and woman with yelow skins, 
 black hair and eyes that slanted to lok 
 
 into the sun. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was now evening, the sky had become dusky and a few
 
 stars had also apeared in the sky. 
 
 God loked down and saw the beautiful rich brown of the
 
 earth and the dusk of the sky for the skin. The black colour
 of the night was for the hair and he used the sparkle of stars
 for the eyes. 
 
 
 Before him stod a man and woman with brown skins, black
 
 hair and eyes. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The animals al loked in wonder at the 
 strange creature who stod on two legs, 
 
 with naked skin, with no fur or feathers or 
 even scales. 
 
 
 The lion loked down his kingly nose and 
 roared, "I can outrun them and with a 
 
 swipe of my paw I can kil them, sory for 
 saying so." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The zebra sugested, "Some stripes
 
 would have improved their lok."
 
 The leopard said, "A few spots."
 
 
 The elephant trumpeted, "Surely grey
 
 would have ben a beter colour?"
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The shark loked at their teth and smiled showing his sharp 
 teth. "Ah! No fins, how wil they swim? And they are going to 
 
 be the keper. Ha! Ha! Ha!" 
 
 The fish, big and smal, laughed as they dived into the dep 
 
 water leaving a trail of bubles of laughter. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 God smiled kindly, "You se, to survive, man wil have to lok
 
 after the animals, the oceans with al their life, the plants,
 from the tiniest to the largest tres." 
 
 
 "The day he starts destroying the world with his gred, he
 wil be destroyed." 
 
 
 The animals, the fish and the birds bowed their heads and
 
 hoped they would be safe. 
 
 So let us, YOU and I, lok after this wonderful world.
